patterns: What is anki
What is SRS
What is spaced repetition system
what does anki do
Whatâ€™s Anki
What is anki study
responses: Anki is the recommended SRS to use with Refold. SRS stands for " Spaced repetition system". SRS are basically flashcards that use an algorithm that attempts to show you information just before you forget them, rather than entirely randomly. This makes studying material much more effective and efficient. Anki is recommended because of the many powerful tools for language learning that make it the best option out there. I recommend you check out the resources below from Refold to learn more about Anki and how it works.
Field-1: This article goes over the SRS and why we use it for language learning
Field-2: This covers the basics of Anki and how to use it.
Related-Q: Do I have to use Anki?

patterns: Do I have to use Anki
Do I need to use Anki
Do I need to use SRS
is anki nessesary
do i have to usue an srs
is srs nessesary
Is Anki necessary
is srs necessary
What if I don't want to use SRS Program
Should I use Anki
responses:
In the end, Anki is just a supplement to the actual method. The primary and most crucial part of Refold is immersion. Anki is just there to help prime words and get them on your radar to make them easier to fully acquire during immersion. Many people have become fluent without ever using Anki or SRS programs.

With that being said, we recommend using Anki. Learning a language is a long journey, and we genuinely do believe that with Anki, the process will go a little faster. If you find Anki a terrible part of the process, then try not going so hard with it. Even 5 words or less a day can help. Just pick a manageable number for yourself and go with it. Even 5 a day is better than nothing and should keep your review time low and manageable.
Field-1: This video goes in detail about why we use the SRS and how to best use it
Field-2: This article goes over some best ways to use the SRS

patterns: Should I do passive immersion during my flashcards
should I do passive immersion while doing my flashcards
should I be doing passive immersion during flashcards
should I be doing passive immersion during anki
should I do passive immersion with anki
When I'm doing my anki deck should be doing passive immersion
should I do passive immersion during anki
should I do passive immersion during anki reps
responses: It is not recommended that you do passive immersion during your SRS/Anki time. Instead, you want to make sure you are only focused on your Anki repetitions to ensure your brain knows that what it is doing is important and should be remembered.

patterns: How do I restart an anki deck
How to start an anki deck fresh
how do you reset an Anki deck
How do i restart my Tango Deck
How do I restart my JP1k deck
How can I restart a deck in Anki
How do I restart a deck in Anki
how do I catch up on a lot of reviews
backlog of reps
how do I catch up in anki
What if I miss a lot of days of anki
What do I do with a large backlog of anki reps
Backlog of anki reps
Anki backlog
how do I handle an Anki backlog
responses:
It is not recommended that you restart a deck. Instead, follow the advice in the article linked below on catching up if you have many built-up reviews.

The reason for this is that even though you won't remember many of the cards, many you will remember. If you start over, you will have to start those known cards fresh, which is a big waste of time. It's better to slowly work through your backlog of due cards. This way, your known cards stay where they are, and forgotten cards begin to refresh.

With that said, if you wish to restart your deck, the best way is to delete the deck and load it in fresh. This ensures all cards are in the intended order (Make sure you still have access to the fresh Anki deck before deleting the old one). You can also select cards from the Anki browser and right-click them, selecting "reschedule..." and sending them to the back of the card queue. This likely will shuffle the cards into a different order than you desired, though, so it isn't preferred.
Field-1: Refold article on how to catch up with a large amount of due cards.
Field-2: This short video goes over how to reset cards if you absolutely must. This is not recommended

patterns: How many cards should I do per day
how much anki should I do per day
how many vocab per day
Is 5 cards per day enough for the JP1K
Is 10 cards per day enough for the JP1K
Is 15 cards per day enough for the JP1K
Is 20 cards per day enough for the JP1K
Is 5 cards per day enough for the Tango
Is 10 cards per day enough for the Tango
Is 15 cards per day enough for the Tango
Is 20 cards per day enough for the Tango
Is 5 cards per day
Is 15 cards per day
Is 20 cards per day
or should i do more
How much Anki a day should I do
How many cards should I do a day
how many vocabulary should I do a day
How many cards should I do for jp1k a day
How many new cards in the jp1k deck should I do a day
how much anki should i do
How many cards in the jp1k deck should I do a day
How many anki cards should i do a day
recommended number of cards per day for JP1K
how much time should i spend per day on anki
responses:
Anki is a supplement to immersion. Many people get into the trap of thinking more Anki means quicker progress. In reality, it's the balance of Anki to immersion that leads to more rapid progress. The recommended amount of cards per day is 10-20, but less is also acceptable. Also, keep in mind that new words will be harder to learn early in the process because you have nothing to associate new words to. So your early cards per day may be much less. Find a balance that works for you.

**Another way to look at cards per day**
Another way to look at cards per day is to not add a specific amount of cards per day at all. Some have found success in allotting a time for Anki rather than a card count. My personal recommendation is that you should be doing a MAX (less is fine) of 30 minutes of Anki for every 1.5 hours of immersion (for a total of 2 hours) with an Anki cap of 2 hours. So at 3 hours of immersion, you have 1 hour of Anki (4 hours total), and at 6 hours of immersion, you cap out at 2 hours of Anki and just add more immersion beyond this. I like this method because it ensures that you don't cut into immersion time to keep up on your Anki card goal.

If you chose the time method above, it's important to note that you always finish your reps for the day. If you run out of time, finish your backlog of cards, but don't add new cards. If you have time, add as many new cards as you can for that day in the remaining time. I do recommend capping your daily cards, though, at 20-30 max, even if you have time remaining, so you trickle cards out and don't have huge swings in cards per day.

patterns: What should I do about leeches
What do I do if i'm getting a lot of leeches
should I delete leeches
what are leeches
What should I do about leaches
what to do with leech card
responses:
Leeches are what happen in Anki when you mark a card wrong a given amount of times. You set this number in deck options, and once this number of times failed is reached, Anki will either tag or delete the card; however you have it set up. Refold believes that constantly hunting for easy, low-hanging fruit that is within your range to learn is the best and fastest method to chipping away at the language. Because of this, we recommend setting your leeches at 5 and allowing leeched cards to suspend or delete.
Note: Every time you get a card wrong, it goes into a **learning** mode. Marking a card incorrect when in learning mode does not add a counter to the leech number. So if you get a card wrong that day, and then that same day you mark it wrong 10 more times without ever getting it correct, this still only counts as 1 leech counter. Only after you mark it correct, then see it again on a different day, will marking it incorrect add a counter to the leech counter.
Field-1: This video goes over low hanging fruit, the snowball effect and why it's so important to progress as it pertains to leeches and accepting ambiguity

responses: The article below will give you the basics of Anki and how to set it up and use it. Anki is not the most user-friendly, intuitive program. People who are not good with computers will have to accept that becoming comfortable with Anki will take some time. I recommend learning the bare minimum to get what you need at that moment and just accept that you will get more and more comfortable with it over time. There are also YouTube videos you can watch going over Anki's basics and advanced features. So if this article doesn't provide enough information, then I recommend looking up some other tutorials on your own.

patterns: What is a good anki retention rate
what should my anki retention rate be
anki retention rate
responses: Ideally, you want to have between a 80-90% retention rate. Anything higher or lower is generally considered to be suboptimal. However, if you are lower, don't worry. You might just need more immersion, add fewer cards per day, or adjust your settings a little bit.
Field-1: MattVsJapan goes over Anki algorithm and adjusting the settings to help fine-tune your retention rate.

patterns: What do I do if I cannot remember a card after failing it several times in a row
fail a card over and over
responses: It is completely fine to fail a card many times. However, always remember to let leeches leech, and never be afraid to suspend a card giving you particular problems. It's better to keep hunting for low-hanging fruit rather than artificially cramming things your brain isn't ready to remember. But that being said, a little bit of cramming is to be expected, especially early on when everything is so new.
Related-Q: What should I do about leeches?

patterns: What font should I use
how do I know if i'm using the right font
responses: Any font that you like and displays Japanese characters should be fine. With that being said, **yuumichou** is the one my creator uses. Using yuumichou you can be sure that you are using a font that displays Japanese Kanji and not Chinese kanji, because they can often be different.

patterns: When should i stop using anki
do you ever stop using anki
do I ever stop using anki
Can I delete Anki
responses: This is a personal choice. In short, use it until you feel you no longer benefit from it. That being said; generally, Refold members continue to use Anki until stage 3 or 4. Once you can understand enough of your immersion to guess unknown words from context alone, you will need Anki less and less. However, some choose to continue using Anki, although almost always at a reduced rate.
Field-1: MattVsJapan video going over not using Anki anymore.

patterns: When should I start using anki
should I start using anki in stage 1
Should I start using Anki for vocabulary even if im at stage 1
Should I use Anki in stage
responses: Basically, from the start, you use Anki. We use Anki to gain a foundation in stage 1 with premade Anki decks and then further build on that foundation in stage 2 with sentence mining. I recommend that you check out all the resources in <#784120941650509865>. The guide posted there will walk you through step by step what to do in stage 1.
Related-Q: What is Anki?  //  How do I get started?  //  How do I learn vocabulary?

patterns: what is LingQ
is Linq any good
should I use lingq
responses: LingQ is a website you can import text into, or chose from their pool of content and use their tools to lookup unknown words and mark words as known or unknown. While it is not a bad tool, we don't feel it is worth the money and that using Netflix, YouTube, etc, with the immersion tools available, such as Yomichan, is just as good if not better. With that being said, though, LingQ is not a bad tool and if you want to try it, go for it.

responses: Language Reactor (formerly Language Learning with Netflix, or LLWNF) is a Chrome add-on that allows you to look up words from Netflix Subtitles as well as navigate subtitles with arrow keys. It's a really great tool, and I recommend checking it out. I recommend using this tool along with Yomichan rather than using the built-in dictionaries.

responses: There are many resources out there, such as Duolingo, Lingodeer etc. While I cant touch on every single last one of them, for the most part these resources are not recomeneded. I recomend checking out the comunity document and finding resources from there that fit better with immersion based learning. That being saidi, almost no resource is **bad**. It's how you use it more than what you use. The problem with resources like Dulingo though are built around activities

patterns: Does Anki count as immersion
is anki immersion
responses: No. Your time in Anki does not count as any type of immersion. It's a suppliment to immersion.

patterns: Will I be fluent if I use duolingo
can i get fluent with duolingo
Can I learn japanese by doing 15 minutes of duolingo per day
responses: If you ONLY use Duolingo and don't pair your time with Duolingo with A LOT of immersion (vastly more time than you spend inside Duolingo), then no. Even 100% completion of Duolingo will not result in very high language ability. Therefore, we do not recommend using Duolingo.

patterns: Is it normal to feel like I can't remember anything after Anki
I feel like Anki does not teach me words
responses: It's normal to feel like words aren't very solidified from Anki. That's because they aren't. Anki's role is to prime words and concepts in your head. But you WILL have a problem remembering those words and concepts outside the SRS. Because the brain is very contextual, it will feel it only needs to remember it when you are using the SRS and have problems recalling outside of it. But, Anki will help get memories started in your brain. To drill in faint familiarity with that vocabulary and concepts so that when you later come across those elements in your immersion, you will be able to acquire them much faster.
Field-1: MattVsJapan video going over this idea.

patterns: When you study an anki card, how long should you spend on 1 card
how long should I spend per card
how long should I take per card
how many seconds per card
responses: While there is a more nuanced, complicated answer to this, for beginners using sentence cards, between 15-30 seconds per card is an acceptable range. As you gain experience, you'll start to form a sense of what is optimal for you. Just be careful not to get caught in the trap of thinking Anki (SRS) is where the magic happens. You want your choices to minimize time and maximize the effectiveness of the SRS so you can spend as much time as possible immersing. The SRS is a supplement to immersion, not the other way around.

So even in the beginning, when you are working through a premade foundation deck, you should be using Anki and getting to learn the program in preparation for sentence mining.

patterns: What is morphman
should I use morphman
is morphman good
can i use morephman
is morphman recomended
responses:
**__Thoughts on morphman and the two camps__**

Morphman is an addon for Anki that attempts to find 1T sentences from a sentence bank. Thoughts on this are split.  So I'll go over the pros and cons, and you can make your own choice.

    Pros Camp:
1. It makes sentence mining quick.
2. Perfect for people with not a lot of time
3. Can use frequency list to find useful words easily.

Cons Camp:
1. Time save is an illusion as all-time sentence mining is not immersion (as opposed to finding sentence while immersing)
2. Morphman can be buggy. It often shows you words you have already marked known. Sorting through this wastes more time.
3. Sentence context is not as concrete and leads to a weaker understanding of the word.
4. Once you have a little sentence mining experience, mining in immersion is faster and leads to better sentences.
5. You are often given 2T+ sentences that appear 1T that make the sentence not very high quality to use.

In the end, it's up to you if you use morphman or not. My Creator (Brett) and many in the server don't like using it. He used to live by it and refused to not use it. When it broke on him, he was forced to sentence mine during immersion, and this was the best thing that happened to him. Being forced into it made him realize how much better an experience it is. However, many also disagree with this and enjoy the addon.

patterns: Tools for iPhone
Tools for android
sentence mining on iphone
sentence mining on android
tools for mobile
sentence mining on mobile
can I immerse on mobile
can i sentence mine on mobile
can i sentence mine on iphone
study on mobile
responses:
As far as immmersion goes, you can do all sorts of things on any mobile phone. You could read books and use built in or third part dictionaries. You can watch Netflix on mobile using the base app, or YouTube. Immersion can be easy. But what about sentence mining and lookup tools.

There is a tool developed for Androidi by a member of the Refold comunity that I have linked below. This allows for sentence mining and lookups on mobile. Sadly there is no equivelent for iPhone (any devs out there want to port the Android app linked below, post it in the Discord.). Reading lookups and sentence making are possible with the Anki app on and just simple copy paste on iPhone, but for now there is no multimedia card creation tools sadly. Only for android.

(Note: There are always to make it work. On iPhone you can listen to your immersion and try and look up words you don't know just by looking up words by hand in the dictionary. Don't let the tools be the reason you don't continue forward. They are nice, but not nessesary. Get your immersion however you can.
Field-1: Android tool for immersion and sentence mining.

patterns: What is low key anki
where can I get low key anki
responses: Low key Anki was an old set of addons to make Anki more productive for language learning purposes. However, the addons are no longer recommended as Refold has developed a method to accomplish the same benefit without addons. This is great because you don't have to worry about the addons being kept up to date; also, it works on mobile. I've linked the Refold recommended settings to accomplish this.
Field-2: This part of the article explains low key Anki in more depth
